commentBody: 8:25, new Friday PB by over a minute. Also beat my Thursday PB by almost a minute

Far too easy for a Friday. 

Nice fill but very average clueing. I liked the clue for TEAT, though.

5/10.
Wow. I liked the cluing, but for some reason this was a lot easier for me than most Friday puzzles. A hair over a four-minute solve, when my usual Friday average is ten minutes.
According to the Oxford English Dictionary, "parka" is originally Nenets (Samoyedic) and found its way into Aleut via Russian.
Can someone eli5  23D?

Once again, spending time with my grandson helped me, because GOTTACATCHEMALL and ITSAME were gimmes.  On the other hand I had never heard of a MOCAPSUIT.  No major hurdles, and nothing that really grabbed my attention.
Have always shied away from Fridays because the clues were often far too obscure for me but today's was surprisingly doable! 14min this time but gonna work on the archives.

Fun puzzle!

Starting to get my rhythm back.

Moderately easy, moderately entertaining.  A mild and reasonable Friday.

I like many, but not all, of the clues left on the cutting room floor.  They would have made this more fun.

Personally the upper left gave me a bit of trouble but was fillable at the end.  Not really a lot to say about this one?

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

PB! 
TGIF!
Quite a few early PBs. Mine was prevented by the crossing of IRS and ATLAS, both Americanisms. (In AU we used the term street directory ‚Äî an atlas was for places that required more than a car.)

I didn't know what Philippics were either, Deb. Fortunately, my crosses were spot on!.
I was well stymied at the first... (base...)

My 3000th puzzle ever! Super fun, northeast corner had me for a while bc while my initial answer made zero sense (sohes/hustle) I thought surely I had a mistake in MOCAPSUIT, but eventually got the right sub letter. Loved the Pok√©mon and Mario references! For those of us (me) who are too young for most of  headlines puzzle and felt frustrated, it felt good to have those as gimmes :)

It's amusing how the first comments here naturally claim that the puzzle was "too easy", allowing them to be the first comments. Personally, I found this puzzle quite challenging because I wasn't familiar with many of the categories (video games, sports, South African money, etc). Plus, I mistakenly thought that this was a Thursday puzzle so I kept looking for the Thursday trick... Oops.

There are so many funny quotes attributed to Yogi Berra (24D), but I think my favorite is (speaking of a restaurant): "Nobody goes there anymore. It's too crowded." This site has a collection of Yogi-isms: - https://yogiberramuseum.org/about-yogi/yogisms/

Mo-cap suit was new to me and I'm glad to know it. I just ordered one on Amazon, so I can live in a CGI world for good, a staged eden of gatorade waterfalls that sparkle in the rain and dirt-cheap prosciutto. You should revoke my artistic license!

I knew Philippics from reading classics in college. Cicero's second Philippic against Marc Antony (ca. 44 BC) contains lines relevant today:

"Ought I not to have complained of the destruction of the Republic, that I might not appear ungrateful to you? And yet in that complaint, piteous and mournful as it was, but, having regard to this position in which the Senate and Roman people have placed me, incumbent on me, what was said by me with insult? What without moderation? What in an unfriendly tone? What a sign indeed of self-control it was, while I was complaining of Marcus Antonius, to abstain from abuse! all the more when you had scattered abroad the last remnants of the constitution; when at your house by the foulest traffic all things were on sale; when you confessed that those laws that had never been advertised  had been proposed for your own behalf and by yourself; when, as augur, you had abolished the auspices, as consul the tribunes' veto; when you were most shamefully fenced round by armed men; when, exhausted with wine and debauchery, you were practicing in your licentious house all forms of impurity."

Ah yes, minus the wine and references to augurs, he could give that speech today, and tomorrow be deported.
Sow with salt was a tasty clue.
Exceptionally easy, probably my fastest Friday time over. Also, CURED HAM is redundant, as all ham is cured by definition.

Easier than usual Thursday and Friday - not that I am in company with the speed demons below. I didn‚Äôt know mo-cap, and had trouble persuading my lone geography neuron to produce Ghana, so was stuck there for a while.

A very fair Friday methinks.  Enjoyable solve

TUNEIN for listening to a podcast seemed kinda off to me. Aren‚Äôt podcasts ‚Äúon demand‚Äù?  
What are we tuning into?
Maybe I‚Äôm too stuck thinking about the linear world I grew up in. 

1 across. A sports clue and I couldn‚Äôt figure it out. Until the very end. I was annoyed until I cussed out the answer.

Left side was easier than right side for me today. Got cured ham almost immediately as I‚Äôm a foodie. Had to think a bit on antelope as while I have never seen S. African money I figured on Springbok, then went to antelope. Got the yogi-ism, but didn‚Äôt think it would be a Berra-ism so lost time there. Nice puzzle though
I can't be the only one to put BIGLOAD for 29A, right? I only changed it when I couldn't figure out what a TOAT would be on a farm

I found this to be a charming Friday puzzle, with crosses that were gentle enough to resolve my unknowns (First or third base? Sherman Act??? Philippics????? The Pokemon tagline?)  

Through it all, it was nice to have Joey tagging alongside me, asking "How you DOIN'?" 
"Hangin' in there, Joey, hangin' in there" until all the pieces started falling into place and I could beam as I answered him "DOIN' great!"

Thank you for a great outing, Boaz and Jacob ‚Äì and congrats to the latter on your NYT debut! I really hope we see more from you.
Does anyone else feel like the ‚Äútricky clues‚Äù they choose are not the ones you find tricky üòÇ
ObPedantry: Cicero did indeed write philippics, but they were a long established literary form by his time. The name comes from Demosthenes's tirades against Philip II, centuries earlier.

Yes it‚Äôs technically an Antelope, but it‚Äôs really the iconic Springbok made famous in the movie Invictus, the symbol of South Africa in general and rugby in particular (2 time defending World Cup champions, and 4 time overall winner - the most of any nation)

I burned through it in under 10 minutes but that‚Äôs not why I liked it. There was so much fun fill and clever clues. Although ICE RAIN is another one of those crossword-isms I would like to send to outer space.

Brag time: I finished it in 32:41 without looking at any of the Down clues. I only used the Acrosses. First time I‚Äôve managed this on a Friday. AT LAST! RARITY!

Great puzzle!
Deb, there's a little typo - in the Constructor Notes, it mentions the original clue for DEEP DIVE but that should be for DEEP END.
I call foul on ICE RAIN. The link doesn't even include the term, it refers to freezing rain. I had ICy RAIN until the bitter end. Crosswordese run amok.
I figured out using "antelope" for 16A but it's a springbok on the coin.

Strands Thread:

Strands #383
‚ÄúOde to the aubergine‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµ

Please no spoilers until after the View All Replies button.

43A was a tough hurdle for me: greenSUIT> MOvieSUIT> what the ** is mockap?? (the pronunciation in my head)

I would have preferred ‚Äúsow with salt‚Äù as it would have saved me from a bad first guess of ‚Äúdeli meat‚Äù for 13A. Also, it‚Äôs pretty funny.

Slow start for me, but had enough toeholds to build on that by the end I was doin‚Äô just fine, thank you, Joey.

This was a lovely one for me. It felt like the cuing were done entirely towarsds my generation.
except that I would happily pay an extra subscription fee to have a sports-free edition - as a sport-agnostic Danish person, I have a hard time even googeling random american ball players, coaches or terms ü§®
for a song = CHEAPASDIRT?? not seeing the connection here. fun puzzle other than that
Fun puzzle. I liked the 'not left in Japan' clue, had me trying to fit in something about driving or cars, filled in then saw 'tip'. Nice.

Dare I say that I think I actually enjoyed a Friday puzzle? I needed two lookups (5 and 11 down), but I just chipped away at it little by little until I finished it (around 5:30 am after waking up way too early). I‚Äôm so glad I stuck with it! It was 9 minutes over my average, but I‚Äôm proud of my perseverance today. Now, back to bed! üò¥

My fastest Friday! It felt like a Wednesday. In any case, I liked it :)
Thrown by FLAP and "to-do", didn't know that they had the "spat" meaning, thank you commenters!
My second best time in a row. IMO, a very easy Friday.
Either that was easy, or I‚Äôm getting smarter!

Hey, Deb, you do a great job. Just one tweak to today‚Äôs column, re: the Sherman Act, though. (Anyone: Feel free to ignore this post if this stuff bores you.)

You might wonder, ‚Äúif the Sherman Act outlaws monopolies, why do they still seem to be all around me?‚Äù The SA doesn‚Äôt outlaw all monopolies. (Common misconception.) So-called ‚Äúinnocent‚Äù monopolies are allowed. e.g. If you just happen to build a better mousetrap than anyone else and all consumers flock to you. In fact, we grant (temporary) monopolies all the time to encourage innovation. (Yeah, Pharma Bros play games to over-exploit this.) What‚Äôs illegal is anticompetitive monopolization‚Äîacting to *inappropriately‚Äù restrict others‚Äô competitive behavior and opportunities. It may sound like a boring quibble, but it is an important distinction, in particular in an age of platforms like Amazon and Google.

Such a fun Friday fling!

Our eldest was born wanting to talk.
I won‚Äôt say *which* parent he takes after,

but it‚Äôs not my husband.

Words by 10 months,
full sentences at about a year,
reading when he was two.

We didn‚Äôt teach him.
Read tons of books, but
who teaches a baby to read?

A Pok√©mon poster 
on the basement door, that‚Äôs who.

He *needed* to memorize the names
cuz, he had to both catch ‚Äòem all,
*and* teach his little brother the names.

He‚Äôd stare at those characters‚Ä¶
we‚Äôd hear a quiet 
‚Äú‚Ä¶mee-owf‚Ä¶‚Äù

120 of them.

CC‚Äôs Useless Parenting Tip #11.

Loved the puzzle, and
really needed the ease and flow of this gem!

Happy, happy Friday all!!

Very enjoyable despite being fast. 

I‚Äôm curious as to the editorial choice to spell Thor‚Äôs belt as megingj√∂rd. Snorri Sturluson spelled it as megingj√∂r√∞ in Old Norse, same as modern Icelandic spells it. This spelling is retained in most modern translations of the Prose Edda.  

I understand opting not to use the edh √∞ in an English language crossword puzzle (hence Thor, not √û√≥rr), but then why retain the √∂? It doesn‚Äôt add anything to the English pronunciation of the word. This is why our anglicized spelling of fj√∂r√∞ is fjord. 

Yes, I‚Äôve veered into seriously pedantic here, but I‚Äôm genuinely puzzled by the broader trends in editing lately.
Maybe it's just that opening day is so soon, but this felt like a nice baseball puzzle to me.
Handful on the farm ü§£ü§£ü§£ü§£

"Oh Thor, not again! Haven't we already established that "ice rain," or "icerain," or "ice-rain," is not a Thing? Even CTRL-F failed to F it on the NOAA webpage--soon to be doged away, no doubt--which Deb linked." (As I remember, someone [CQ?], established that "icerain" was perhaps the product of AI auto-translations, from the German "Eisregen.")

OTOH, icy, freezing rain is definitely a Thing, as I found several times this past winter, driving in Northern (Lower, RiA) Michigan. Better get off this freeway ASAP, at the next exit, before I kill myself. Not familiar with the backroads in this part of the state? Luckily I have my handy DeLorme¬Æ Atlas and Gazeteer of Michigan, wedged between passenger seat and the shift console. (Pull safely off to the side of the road before consulting.) The other, of Ohio, is in the back seat; and several (but not 48) more are at home, on the book shelf.
I didn‚Äôt ‚Äúknow‚Äù ITSAME, but smiled when I got it‚Ä¶ might start using that one myself!

Showing my age again. I knew PHILIPPIC from the Simon and Garfunkel song on their first (?) album: A Simple Desultory Philippic.

But so much else was only obtainable from the crosses, such as MOCAP SUIT. 

As for ANTELOPE, I can't even read the words South Africa without becoming nauseated.

[Target of many 2025 acts]

TRUST

And continuing with the ‚ÄúNews‚Äù:
CHEAPASDIRT MEDIADARLINGS

(Fun puzzle today. The long-term forecast: continuing trend of easier solves with frequent ICERAIN.)

Random reactions:
‚Ä¢	Star of the puzzle, IMO, is that cross of lovely phrases right in the center ‚Äì MEDIA DARLINGS and CHEAP AS DIRT, both NYT answer debuts, by the way.
‚Ä¢	Loveliness spread around as well, with TEETER, RARITY, RUSTLE, and ARTISTIC LICENSE.
‚Ä¢	ITSAME is a DOOK.
‚Ä¢	PuzzPair¬© of TEETER and TIP.
‚Ä¢	Sincerely wondering if the IRS still has a Commissioner. 
‚Ä¢	Ahh, that BERRA quote ‚Äì ‚ÄúIf the world were perfect, it wouldn‚Äôt be‚Äù.  Ain‚Äôt that the truth?  It‚Äôs why I smile at the imperfections baked into Yogi‚Äôs well-known quotes.
‚Ä¢	Serendipities: IT bunched together three times in the SW corner, schwa-enders (GHANA, MEDIA, PARKA, BERRA, GOTTA, ITSA), and the echo of SHAMAN in the grid and ‚ÄúSherman‚Äù in a clue.

 I just kept building off of crosses in a path that resembled a scribble, and the next thing I knew, I was done.  So in addition to giving me much to bounce off of, this was great fun. Thank you so much, Boaz and Jacob!

I did not know about ‚ÄúGator-aid.‚Äù From Wikipedia:
‚ÄúThe University of Florida researchers initially considered naming their product "Gator-Aid", but eventually settled on "Gatorade". Darren Rovell notes in his history of Gatorade, First in Thirst, "the doctors realized that they probably shouldn't use the 'Aid' suffix, since that would mean that if the drink were ever marketed, they would have to prove that it had a clear medicinal use and perform clinical tests on thousands of people."Gatorade co-inventor Dana Shires explained, "We were told that you couldn't use that because the Food and Drug Administration prohibited that. That would classify it as something other than a cola or soft drink, so we changed it to ade."‚Äù

Another Friday puzzle that treated me quite gently. All the long entries dropped easily into place, and even the unknown MOCAPSUIT made perfect sense once I looked at it.

Last time it appeared, the very unfortunate ICERAIN was a single entry, and was clued as "Cold-weather driving hazard". Of course, there's no such thing, but it seems the editorial staff insists on foisting it upon us, today intentionally pairing ICE and RAIN to create this non-existent English compound word. In English we say "freezing rain", not Eisregen. 

On an alphabetical note, this grid was packed with very common letters. Looks like the K in SPARKLES was the sole "interesting" letter in the puzzle.
One again ICE RAIN appears in a puzzle, but I have never heard anyone refer to freezing rain in that way. What part of the country uses that terminology?

Mario says "itsume", not "itsame". 
Aren't editors supposed to correct things like that?

What a delight! Not my fastest Friday puzzle, but the first where I didn't have any look-ups. Very grateful for the baseball centric questions here (and my boyfriend's inexplicable love of a sport that doesn't even exist in our country)‚Äîusually it's the US-centric questions that catch me out. Thank you Boaz and Jacob!
Thanks for baseball clues.
It is actually itsumi mario which translates to super mario

Funny the rabbit-holes one falls down. Several posts below, I mentioned that the last time ICE RAIN appeared in the puzzle, someone had found that, on the web, most instances of that term were from Auto-translations from German, in which "Eisregen" is a real noun.

Turns out that Eisregen is also the name of a German death metal band, notable in that several of their albums have been banned in Germany (by the Federal Department for Media Harmful to Young Persons), for lyrics which are "cruel, inhuman, misogynistic and violent."

Several of their songs have been posted to youtube, which I shall not link.

This was really a great themeless puzzle to work through. Seldom am I this impressed by a themeless. Dynamic, clever and fluid like molasses. It was a slow and sweet solve.

Some of my family tree has roots in farming, TEAT made me chuckle. Although milking is usually done by machine these days, who doesn‚Äôt want to try their hand at it just for fun?

When I was 43 years old, my father finally came around as a father, and apologized for being a terrible, neglectful one during my childhood. He gave me a Gameboy that came with a POKEMON game for my birthday that year. I was stunned that he would even think to purchase such a novel thing. Then realized he had actually put some thought into it, and that was really a novel thing.

I was addicted to playing POKEMON every spare minute for quite a while. I still have my POKEMON games and Gameboy tucked away in a box with other happy memories.
Loved this one!

Hoping to hear fewer cries of "Too easy/fast/etc." for this enjoyable puzzle with its interesting entries.  
My first word into the grid was PERU--a guess based on the linguistic features of the canyon name.
Had to backtrack at 18A PIRATE before RAIDER.

Most reluctant entry:  MOCAPSUIT.  My thought was "MOCK UP SUIT" but that wouldn't fit, and the crosses were also insiistent.  What exactly does MOCAP stand  for??

I'm  unfamiliar with Pokemon and Mario--a situation that is unlikely to change.  After all, I still have an ATLAS.  

27D calls to mind the scene in "Witness" where Harrison Ford is assisting the Amish farmer (Rip Torn) with the milking--or trying to.

TIL MOCAPSUIT. Got it through the crosses. 
Perfectly fair Friday. One answer filled led to another, and, poof!, finished. TGIF!
Feel like my (F24) youth is showing. The crossing of "To-do" and "For a song" made no sense to me. Needed the comments to help finish today!

Despite more than usual that I was unfamiliar with, I was able to finish in a decent amount of time. Quite enjoyable for a Friday! No chewed nails (as if I would do that to my expensive nails!), and only one cuppa. Now, off to the ER for my shift. See you all tomorrow!
The ‚Äútricky clue‚Äù for 38D [Philippics] doesn‚Äôt actually include the answer?

Suddenly, any Comment automatically "requests" notification, whether you want it or not. 
It's getting tedious to unclick the bright blue box.  Also, blue outlines appear unbidden if you click to Reply to a Comment.

Have you nothing better to do, NYT Game Folk?
Fun and fresh.

Back me up here, fellow fashionistas:

Thor doesn't wear Megingjord, Megingjord wears him.

@Deb Amlen

A couple of Wordplay corrections:

While Cicero did write a set of Philippics (against Mark Antony), the origin of the term is from the TIRADES of Demosthenes against the imperialist tendencies of PHILIP II of Macedon (Alexander's dad).

Two mistakes in the Constructor Notes:
DEEP END, not DEEP dive
and
ALES not I.P.A.S.
"Getting to first base" was always a struggle for me as a kid baseball player or as a teen Romeo but I finished this Friday in 35:47 at age 81! There is hope!

Dog's motto: "Gotta fetch 'em all!"

(No bones about it!)

Came so close to solving this without lookups but the middle section completely stumped me and I didn‚Äôt want to spend all day on it. Can someone help me understand why 27D isn‚Äôt a plural? Would you say ‚Äúhandful of coin‚Äù? It would be ‚Äúhandful of coins‚Äù, no? Ergo: ‚Äúhandful of teats‚Äù?

TOOCUTE about sums it up.

Thank you Boaz and Jacob

Nice puzzle. The unfamiliar info was mostly filled in with the crossing words. (I did know the Pokemon slogan, only because it was quoted in jokes and cartoons not too long ago.) Mario's introduction gives hope that Chico Marx could find new friends among people younger than me. The baseball clues were lovely -- "A short walk from home" made me laugh. Had to use the answer key, but nope, MOCAPSUIT is a real thing.

Hands up: How many people first filled in "Pirate" for Corsair?

Where do people makes comments on today's Strands? Thanks.
Quick, easy and fun
Aaayyyy best Friday yet for me!

All the hue and cry over ICERAIN. My wife is not a native speaker of English, and she'll use terms like that. It may take me a second or two to get what she means, but the notion that language is descriptive rather than prescriptive is more appealing. 

I thought this grid was a little too easy for a Friday. It took a little less time than Wednesday's and Thursday's puzzles, and just a bit longer than Monday's and Tuesday's, so it's been an oddly flat week like that. That said, of course, I have a feeling I'll be gobsmacked by Saturday's puzzle.

Good Friday with interesting fill. Slightly distracted as waiting to hear when my son can get home from Bangkok. He‚Äôs stranded as Heathrow airport is closed. Can‚Äôt believe a fire in one sub station can shut down one of the world‚Äôs busiest airports! At least he wasn‚Äôt in the air and diverted to who knows where. Flying eh? Think I‚Äôll stick to the train (when they run).
There are things worse than ICE RAIN. There's Pencil Rain. https://youtu.be/UqlxbQxNHso?feature=shared
TUNEIN to a podcast? Holy boomer clue Batman!

I‚Äôm not here to defend ICE(-)RAIN as an ‚Äúin the language‚Äù equal to freezing rain, ice pellets, sleet, driving slush, or hailstones the size of golf balls. Clearly, the phrase is a rare phenomenon. But I posted this little bit of Canadian weather journalism last time the storm clouds gathered around the puzzling weather terminology, so for consistency and secretly hoping to see it become more common: https://www.saobserver.net/local-news/winter-storm-warning-issued-for-eaglerogers-pass-salmon-arm-hit-with-ice-rain-7691224

Today I learned the term MOCAP SUIT.
I suspect that I'm not the only one.

Although I've know of their existence for some time as an aid to CGI film-making, but I had never seen the word.

It's basically a black suit with ping-pong balls glued to it.

It's amusing to think of your favorite superhero being filmed.  In the final movie, they may be flying across the sky, shooting fireballs out of their fists, but, in "reality", they're lying on a table in front of a green screen, wearing a black suit with ping-pong balls glued on it.
Some hero!

Ice Rain is not a real thing, term, name, idiom, euphemism, or anything else. The end.  I get so tired this level of arrogance. Not to mention that the image on a Krugerrand is specifically a springbok and we're proud of it.
while my frugality has prompted unflattering comparisons when purchasing something that is "dirt cheap", i have never been called "cheap as dirt".

If anyone's interested in our original pitches for ICE and RAIN, we had [Solid that's denser than its liquid form] and [Fall in the spring?]. 

I didn't think to investigate ICE RAIN's legitimacy when they sent the proofs over. Sounded like a thing to me! I'm fascinated by all the research here, especially regarding its translation from German.

I checked on my wordlist, and at some point I downscored ICE RAIN to where it wouldn't be used. So all the ICE RAIN dislikers will be happy to know ICE RAIN will almost certainly not be in future puzzles.
The northwest corner really baffled me -- I confidently entered "pirate" for 18A and who "dis" for 25A and it went downhill from there. I really enjoyed ITSAME, though!

Yes, it was a faster Friday than usual perhaps, but really clever and enough that was out of my Baby Boomer wheelhouse to make me work the crosses. I too loved those long down spanners. 
Thanks for the fun, Boaz and Jacob. Looking forward to your next collaboration or solo offering.

Hi! We‚Äôre having getting our Thursday 3/20 puzzle recognized as completed. We even erased and redid it. When we finish, it indicates we are done but our 701 day streak isn‚Äôt updated.
Please correct this for us.

I was so excited to see "Philippics" because I had no idea what it was and looked forward to a chewy quadrant. However, what slowed me down was not the clue I knew I didn't know, but a clue I thought I did know.

I confidently entered mAw for 6D, then couldn't figure out what might be on the Kruggerand. Well, I figured it out, but it was the last to fall.

Slight panic when first go-around came up with almost nothing and settled in for a slog, but came through in the end and emerged victorious.

(Enjoyed the baseball clues.)

Late to the party. Did this one early this morning as usual but then had a busy day. Anyway.. typical tough Friday for me and a couple of completely unfamiliar things. Had to look up a couple of terms but managed to get through it. Unusual puzzle find today. A Sunday from September 8, 2013 by Pete Muller and Sue Keefer with the title: "Bumper cars." Five grid spanning 21 letter theme answers and two more theme answers 18 letters long. Some examples: "Search for a cradle-robbing woman in New York City?" PARKAVENUECOUGARQUEST "High-handed ambassador stationed off the Italian coast?" CAVALIERCAPRIDIPLOMAT "Tom Brady, in the 2002 Super Bowl?" INTREPIDRAMCHALLENGER "Musical piece for a "Star Wars" battle scene?" STORMTROOPERSONATA "Diminutive Aborigine?" MIDGETOUTBACKEXPLORER And there were more. Don't think I would have any chance at solving that one. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=9/8/2013&g=23&d=A ...

A "gentler Friday romp" is an apt description of my puzzle experience today. I just blew through this one - once I got going, that is. (Thanks again, ETSY! You're my favorite crossword pal!) I only hit a small speed bump near the end when I too confidently filled in OAHU, but PERU soon emerged to set me straight. Thanks for the fun!
I can never remember where the c's and s's go (wait, is there an s?)  in license ... or is it licence? That hurt me today. By tomorrow, I'll have forgotten again.
Handful on a farm... really??

Cicero's Philippics were in turned named after a series of speeches by Demosthenes of Athens in which he tried to turn public opinion against the growing power of Philip of Macedon (father of Alexander, of course).
Did anybody else think it‚Äôs worse to blow a BIG LOAD?
@Mark Phaedrus and I was feeling good about my new 8:25 Friday PB
@Mark Phaedrus In fairness, I‚Äôd say if your average is ten minutes, every Friday is easy for you.
@Mark Phaedrus we originally envisioned it as a Saturday with significantly more obtuse clueing.

@Jacob 
It probably doesn‚Äôt really feel like your crossword any more. Cannot believe they got rid of [Sow with salt?]. Look forward to your next one.

@Fact Boy 
At the Sitka Salvation Army store, no doubt.
@Yukon Bruce A flap is another word for argument, fight and such. To-do is the same. At least that‚Äôs how I define them. Others might have more nuanced analogies.

@Yukon Bruce it‚Äôs just a regular run of the mill dictionary definition. (In American English)

A a flap is a ‚Äúto do‚Äù..   just a little ripple in an otherwise peaceful day.

@Yukon Bruce
I wonder if flapping something to fan the flames is a contributor to the history of the usage? 

Maybe  I‚Äôve just been watching ‚ÄúSurvivor‚Äùcontestants making fire. 

I had ‚Äúfuss‚Äù before the crosses led to FLAP.
@Yukon BruceTIL eli5

@spurious 

Here it was called a "road atlas" or just street map.  The big book that stayed home was still called an atlas.

And the fancier folks who belonged to the American Automobile Association (auto club) could get custom TripTiks that were point to point highlighted Google Maps routes many decades before the World Wide Web.


____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@B 

In Polish we rarely use (or used...) te word "atlas" without an adjective or noun as additional descriptor. Road atlas was "atlas samochodowy" (literally, car atlas. Samoch√≥d is Polish for car: it literally means a thing that goes/walks by itself, or possibly one you yourself make go). The big one of the whole world was either "atlas ≈õwiata" (world atlas) or "atlas powszechny" (universal/common atlas). There were also "atlasy kieszonkowe" (pocket atlases) we would take to school for geography lessons. Others, to. I really liked them. Looking at the maps helped me imagine I was travelling around the whole world. Online maps are more convenient but don't have the same magic...

@Andrzej 

Thank you, google Android autocorrect, for not correcting my typos.

@Andrzej

At the dawn of automobilism, Polish also used "automobil", but these days it is 100% archaic. We always say either samoch√≥d or auto, the latter being sometimes frowned upon by language purists. We pronounce auto differently than you do, obviously, the "au" sounding like and the "to" as the "to" on "torrid" (rather than toe, for example).

@Shrike

@Shrike

@Shrike 

Yeah, but doesn't including a redundant adjective make it more expressive?

For example, I, not having much on the ball, don't know that *all* ham is cured.  So if someone says, "Want some ham?"  I might create an embarrassing situation for everyone by asking "Is it cured?"

On the other hand, if the person is nice enough to say "Want some cured ham?",  I won't look like an idiot.

And not looking like an idiot is always important to me.

All evidence to the contrary.
